backend_description: The image shows six rays labeled A through F meeting at a central point labeled G. Rays AG and GD form a straight horizontal line, while rays BG and EG, and CG and FG, form intersecting lines that create multiple angles around point G. The angle AGC lies between rays AG and CG.
question_type: Multiple Choice Question with Single Answer
solution:
Look at $\angle$AGC and $\angle$FGA.
$\angle$FGA is supplementary to $\angle$AGC. Together they form a straight line, which has a measure of 180°. So, their angles add up to 180°.
solution_image_tag: The image shows six rays—AG, BG, CG, DG, EG, and FG—that all meet at a common point labeled G. Rays AG and DG form a straight horizontal line. Rays BG and EG form another straight line that slants upward to the left and downward to the right, while CG and FG form a third line that slants upward to the right and downward to the left. These intersecting lines create several angles around point G. The angle ∠AGC is formed between rays AG and CG. A green arc marks ∠AGC, and a blue arc marks the adjacent angle ∠FGA, which together form a straight line.
